ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about gene-editing and the amount of work that researchers put into the early stages of designing a gene-editing experiment.

I learned a lot about writing a scientific research paper, using bioinformatics tools, and studying primary literature research. Specifically, I got to study the genetic controls behind tomato flavor.
I learned how to use a bioinformatics approach to investigating gene function.
Became comfortable using tools such as: Genome Data Viewer, SeqBuilder, EnsemblPlants
I learned a lot of science writing and bioinformatic skills
Scientific writing and gene editing skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Moreno was a great scientist to learn from, provided a lot of valuable feedback, and really helped with trouble-shooting and other online issues.

The course taught us a lot of skills that are commonly used in biological research. The major strength of this course was that it walked us through the process of writing a scientific research paper step-by-step. I think this is very important for anyone going into STEM, and I feel better prepared because of it. The only weakness was that the work wasn't evenly distributed throughout the semester. Some weeks we wouldn't have much to do at all, and other weeks we had to do tons of research/writing.

Having us do the "behind-the-scenes" work to design an experiment was an interesting premise for a virtual lab course. However, I think the pacing of this course could be improved. We spent a lot of time in the beginning searching the literature, which did not leave very much time to explore the BioInformatics tools at the end.
I thought the teaching for this course was fantastic
This course was well-adjusted to COVID-19. The main improvement would be to have it in person.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish the lab was maybe shorter because I found it quite difficult to focus for 2+ hours. Otherwise, it was a great online lab class.

I think the virtual lab sessions were really helpful especially because Prof. Moreno made a point to check in with all of us individually each week. Even though labs were long on Zoom, Prof. Moreno made sure to give us breaks when we needed them and tried her best to keep us all engaged.
I thought the idea of doing a class based on a project was wonderful
Transition to gene editing design needed no in person components, so it was effective.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, especially for the MCDB major lab requirement. You learn a lot of techniques that are applicable to other labs / a future in STEM.

I would definitely recommend this course because you learn so much about designing/writing about biological research. Unlike other lab courses, you get to walk through an entire research project from beginning to end. In addition, Prof. Moreno cares so much about her students, and being in her class will brighten up your day.
yes! I think this class is an excellent way to learn bioinformatic skills
Yes, Doctor Moreno is excellent.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also a bit of a lecture and seminar format for this lab.
none other
